0.text: Social phobia, or social anxiety disorder, shows up as intense anxiety in situations involving social interaction. Asking for help is one of the everyday situations that can be very stressful for people with social anxiety.
0.fact: Charles Darwin, the famous naturalist and author of the theory of evolution, struggled with severe social anxiety. He avoided public appearances and often experienced panic attacks before having to interact with people, despite his outstanding achievements.

1.text: Glossophobia is the fear of public speaking and is one of the most common forms of social anxiety. Around 75% of people experience some degree of fear before speaking in public.
1.fact: According to a survey by the American Psychological Association, about 30% of Americans report strong fear of public speaking, making it one of the most widespread fears.

2.text: One of the key aspects of social anxiety is fear of interacting with unfamiliar people. This can show up as avoiding contact, trying to remain unnoticed, and feeling awkward or anxious.
2.fact: Writer Franz Kafka lived with severe social anxiety and often struggled to talk to strangers. His works, such as “The Trial” and “The Castle”, reflect deep fears and feelings of alienation.

3.text: People with social anxiety often avoid phone calls and video meetings because they’re afraid of being misunderstood or making a bad impression. They may worry about how their voice sounds or what exactly they will say.
3.fact: One way to reduce anxiety before phone calls is practising and preparing in advance. Writing down key points or questions can help a person feel more confident and less fearful.

4.text: Social anxiety can lead people to avoid communication outside of obligatory contexts (such as work or study) so they don’t have to face potentially stressful social situations.
4.fact: Studies suggest that around 15 million Americans (about 7% of the population) live with social anxiety, and many of them prefer to stay away from social situations beyond their required roles.

5.text: Entering a room where everyone is already seated can be especially stressful for people with social anxiety because of the fear of being the center of attention. They may worry that others are looking at them or judging them.
5.fact: Albert Einstein, the great physicist, also struggled with strong social anxiety and avoided large gatherings. He preferred working alone and communicating only with close friends and colleagues.

6.text: People with social anxiety may experience criticism very painfully, especially on social media where comments are public and visible to many.
6.fact: Digital detox is becoming more popular: many people, including public figures, periodically step away from social media to protect their mental health and reduce exposure to negative feedback.

7.text: Staying silent in meetings can be a way to avoid negative attention and possible criticism, but it may also limit career growth and professional opportunities.
7.fact: Active listening techniques can help people feel more confident in meetings. For example, focusing on listening and preparing a couple of questions or comments in advance can lower anxiety and make it easier to participate.

8.text: Social anxiety is marked by strong worry in situations where a person might be evaluated by others. Being asked to share an opinion in front of a group is one of those situations and can trigger fears of making a mistake or being judged negatively.

9.text: People with social anxiety may feel very uncomfortable and tense in crowded places like the subway. Such environments can trigger fears of being noticed, judged or drawn into unexpected social interactions.
9.fact: Adele, the well-known British singer, has spoken about her social anxiety and panic attacks. She avoids crowded places such as the underground to reduce the risk of intense anxiety symptoms.

10.text: People with social anxiety often try not to be the center of attention so they don’t attract extra interest or criticism. They may fear negative comments or ridicule, which reinforces the wish to stay in the background.

11.text: According to the U.S. National Institute of Mental Health, about 12.1% of people experience social anxiety disorder at some point in their lives, and this frequently leads to avoiding public places.

12.text: Research shows that a moderate level of anxiety can actually improve performance by activating the sympathetic nervous system and boosting concentration. This is known as the Yerkes–Dodson law.

13.text: Anxiety before social interaction is known as social anxiety and can range from mild discomfort to intense fear. It is considered the third most common mental health condition after depression and alcohol dependence.

14.text: Fear of interacting with authority figures is sometimes called “hierarchophobia”. This is not an official medical diagnosis, but the term is often used to describe heightened worry when dealing with people in higher positions.
14.fact: Warren Buffett, one of the most successful investors in the world, once struggled with strong fear of public speaking and talking to authority figures. He signed up for a course to work through this fear, which later had a big positive impact on his career.

15.text: Fear of going to shopping malls can be linked to agoraphobia — fear of open spaces or places where it might be hard to leave quickly. It can also be a manifestation of social anxiety or ochlophobia (fear of crowds).

16.text: Psychologists call fear of the unknown “intolerance of uncertainty”. It can affect not only social situations but decision-making in general, making any new or unfamiliar experience feel threatening.

17.text: Fear of performing in front of an unfamiliar audience is called “fear of social evaluation”. It combines worry about being judged by others with anxiety about new situations.
17.fact: Actress Emma Stone has spoken openly about her struggle with panic attacks, especially around public performances in new settings. She uses therapy and breathing techniques to help manage these experiences.

18.text: Fear of phone calls is sometimes called “phone phobia”. It is becoming more common in the digital age, as many people grow more used to text-based communication than voice calls.
18.fact: A 2019 BankMyCell study found that 76% of millennials feel anxious about making phone calls. Among Generation Z, the number was even higher — around 81%.

19.text: Anxiety about returning items to a store can be linked to fear of conflict, fear of negative judgment or a sense of guilt for “causing inconvenience” to staff.
19.fact: This type of anxiety is often part of a broader pattern called “assertophobia” — fear of standing up for one’s rights or expressing one’s needs.

20.text: Fear of being asked to speak without preparation is often connected to impostor syndrome — the feeling that you are not competent enough and might be “exposed”.
20.fact: Practising an improvisational mindset can be helpful. Instead of panicking because you haven’t prepared, you can try to treat the situation as an opportunity for honest, spontaneous conversation with the audience.

21.text: Fear of writing or taking notes in front of others is sometimes referred to as “scriptophobia”. It is a specific form of social anxiety linked to fear of being watched and judged.
21.fact: There are no exact statistics on how common this fear is, but a study published in the Journal of Anxiety Disorders found that about 7% of people feel strong discomfort when they have to write in the presence of others.

22.text: Difficulty saying no, especially to pushy people, is related to what psychologists sometimes call “people-pleasing” or an excessive need to be liked. It often stems from a wish to avoid conflict and fear of negative judgment.
22.fact: A study at the University of Pennsylvania found that around 68% of people feel uncomfortable when they need to say “no” in sales situations.

23.text: Martin Luther King Jr., the famous civil rights leader, also experienced strong anxiety about expressing his views in front of groups early in his career. By repeatedly facing his fears, he eventually became one of the most powerful speakers and human rights advocates in history.

24.text: People with social anxiety may feel strong stress and worry when they receive unexpected invitations to weddings or other celebrations. Such events often involve many people and social interactions, which can be particularly challenging.
24.fact: Daniel Radcliffe, known for his role as Harry Potter, has spoken about his social anxiety and often avoids large public events, preferring time with small groups of friends and family.

25.text: People with social anxiety often avoid making phone calls when others are nearby because they fear being overheard and judged. They may worry about how their voice sounds, about making mistakes in speech or about others reacting negatively to their conversation.

26.text: Avoiding parties can be a form of “safety behaviour” — a strategy that reduces anxiety in the short term but, over time, can increase social isolation and make fears stronger.

27.text: Studies suggest that about 7–9% of people live with paruresis, also known as “shy bladder syndrome”, which can lead them to avoid using public toilets.

28.text: People with social anxiety may feel particularly anxious when they receive invitations to meet or go on a date. Common reasons include fear of negative evaluation, low self-confidence and worries about saying or doing something “wrong”.

29.text: Fear of answering phone calls, especially from unknown numbers, can be linked to worry about not knowing how to respond or that the conversation may go in an uncomfortable direction. It may include fear of confrontation or of having to answer unexpected questions on the spot.

30.text: People with social anxiety can feel very tense when talking to strangers while travelling or on holiday. They may be afraid of negative evaluation, doing something inappropriate or not knowing how to keep the conversation going.

31.text: Research shows that about 60% of people with social anxiety feel uncomfortable making eye contact. This can be one of the most stressful aspects of social interaction for them.

32.text: People with social anxiety may feel strong tension at the thought of conflicts or arguments with strangers. They may worry about negative evaluation, misunderstanding or aggression, which leads them to avoid any potentially confrontational situations.

33.text: Studies suggest that around 20–30% of people feel significant discomfort when being photographed, especially in groups. This anxiety is often linked to fear of negative evaluation and dissatisfaction with one’s appearance.

34.text: Isaac Newton, the great scientist, was also very reserved and avoided taking part in public events or new groups. He preferred to spend his time alone, focused on his research.

35.text: Research shows that cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) can be very effective in treating social anxiety. CBT helps people change negative thinking patterns and develop a more supportive attitude toward social interactions.

36.text: Anxiety before practical or performance exams is very common, especially among people with social anxiety. Fear of being evaluated and the possibility of failure can intensify stress and nervousness.
36.fact: Inventor Thomas Edison had difficulty with traditional teaching methods and exams. He preferred to learn through experiments and hands-on work, often avoiding formal testing.

37.text: People with social anxiety often feel intense worry when talking to others. Fear of negative evaluation, concern about how their words will be perceived and worry about making mistakes can significantly increase anxiety.

38.text: People with social anxiety often prefer to go for walks at times when there are few or no people outside. This helps them avoid social interactions that might trigger anxiety and stress.
38.fact: Howard Hughes, the famous American businessman and aviator, known for his social anxiety and multiple phobias, preferred solitary walks and avoided crowded places, trying to remain unnoticed and limit social contact.

39.text: Eye contact activates mirror neurons, which can strengthen feelings of empathy and connection but also trigger strong emotions. This may be one of the reasons why eye contact can feel so anxiety-provoking.

normal.text: Your results suggest that you generally feel confident in most social situations. Contact with unfamiliar people, taking part in discussions or speaking in front of an audience typically does not cause you strong discomfort. This means you can interact with others freely and usually feel at ease in social settings.
normal.title: No signs of social anxiety

mild.text: Your answers indicate that certain social situations can bring tension or self-doubt. Talking to unfamiliar people, speaking up or being the center of attention may feel stressful at times. This is a very common experience, and with support and practice your confidence can grow noticeably over time.
mild.title: Moderate social anxiety

moderate.text: Your results suggest that social situations may cause you significant anxiety and discomfort. This can affect your self-confidence and your willingness to engage with other people. These feelings can be exhausting, but with support and a willingness to work on this condition, it is possible to gradually reduce anxiety and feel more free and secure in communication.
moderate.title: Pronounced social anxiety

text: How comfortable do you feel in social situations? Anxiety around conversations, meeting new people or speaking in front of others is a very common reaction.

This test can help you better understand your relationship with social interactions and the possible level of social anxiety. Noticing your own reactions is an important step towards building confidence and feeling calmer and more at ease around other people.
